items.message:
River levels are remaining high on the River Greta, River Derwent, Derwentwater lake level.
Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwentwater and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site.
Further rainfall is forecast overnight which will cause both the river and lake levels to rise. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated on the morning of Saturday the 7th of January, or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River levels are remaining high on the River Greta, River Derwent, Derwentwater lake level.
Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwentwater and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site.
Further rainfall is forecast overnight which will cause both the river and lake levels to rise. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This alert will remain in force for several days. This message will be updated on Saturday the 7th of January or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck

items.message:
River levels are high and forecast to rise further on the Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck due to rainfall across the evening of Friday the 6th into Saturday the 7th of January. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the weekend which will cause the rivers to remain high.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck but no property flooding is expected.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:
Further rainfall is forecast during the evening of Friday the 6th of January into the morning of Saturday the 7th. This will cause river levels to rise further on the Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster. Lake Windermere will also remain high for several days. No property flooding is expected.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated on Saturday the 7th of January or as the situation changes.

The flood alert for the North Sea Coast at Bridlington has been issued for Saturday morning’s tide (07/01/2023) between 6 am and 8.30 am and for Saturday evening’s tide between 5pm and 9.30 pm. This is due to onshore winds and wind-blown spray. The particular area of concern is Bridlington Lifeboat Station and South Pier. Please take care around exposed promenades and roads where spray may create hazardous conditions. This message will be updated by 10 am on Saturday 07/1/2023

This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast for tomorrow morning 07/01/23. The forecast high water is at 9:27am with a level of 1.30 mAODN with Southerly force 8 winds (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables). Areas most at risk are Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Rivers Avon and Stour. All flood gates have been closed. We will continue to monitor levels closely. This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 07/01/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message: A flood alert has been issued for tomorrow mornings tides 7/01/23. The morning high tides between approximately 06:30am and 10:00am are higher than normal due to unsettled weather with south westerly force 8 winds and large waves. Areas most at risk are Swanage and Preston Beach. We continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 07/01/2023, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are forecast to rise on the River Wey as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of footpaths and farmland is possible tomorrow, 07/01/23, especially in the Godalming and Bordon areas. Levels have fallen over the last few days after a mostly dry period but are likely to respond to the showers expected over the weekend particularly on the Hell Ditch.

Further heavy rainfall is forecast over this evening and throughout the weekend. We expect river levels to begin rising over the weekend.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are in the area clearing weed and trash screens. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow afternoon, 07/01/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of rainfall expected this evening and overnight tonight. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is likely to begin at approximately 10:00 tomorrow morning, Saturday 07/01/23.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road. Further intermittent light rainfall is forecast over Saturday and Sunday. We expect river levels to remain high throughout the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 21:00 tonight, 06/01/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Lilbourne river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding of roads and farmland remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until 16:00 on 08/01/23.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels remain high on the River Avon through Bradford on Avon and Bathford. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Further rain is forecast tomorrow Saturday the 07 January 2023  with a further 3 to 15mm possible. Expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. Flooding of low-lying land and roads is possible between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers and do not drive through flood water. We are monitoring the situation and checking for blockages in rivers.

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are forecast to rise on the Chertsey Bourne as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding continues, especially in the Chertsey area. Levels have remained steady over the drier period the last few days, but will be impacted by the showers tonight and over the weekend, with a peak forecast on Sunday morning. 

Further heavy rainfall is forecast over this evening and throughout the weekend. We expect river levels to begin rising tomorrow morning 07/01/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are in the area clearing weed and trash screens. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' web page for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow afternoon, 07/01/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels have fallen but are forecast to rise at the Willington Cableway river gauge as a result of consistent rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. We expect river levels to steadily rise over the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 12:30 tomorrow, 07/01/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Lizard Point to Gribbin Head excluding Truro City
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Saturday morning 07 January. High water at Truro is at 05.27am, times of high water will vary along the coast.
Strong force 8 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of between 4 and 5m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal areas. Locations particularly at risk include low lying areas along the tidal rivers Helford and Fal, including the A39 at Perranarworthal, and exposed coastal locations including Portmellon seafront, Mevagissey Harbour area, and Portholland.  Expect tides to be around 530mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Truro is 2.73 mAOD, this is 0.53 metres above astronomical tide level.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message: This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast for tomorrow morning 07/01/23. The forecast high water is at 9:57am with a level of 1.20 mAODN with Southerly force 8 winds (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables). Areas most at risk include Poole Harbour, Wareham and tidal stretches of the Lower Frome and River Piddle two hours either side of the high tide. We will continue to monitor levels closely. This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 07/01/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Devon coast from Start Point to Dawlish Warren
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Saturday morning. High water at Exmouth is at 06:45. Times of high water will vary along the coast. Strong force 7 southerly winds and waves may cause spray overtopping. People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.   

  

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Exmouth is 2.31mAOD, this is 0.53 metres above the astronomical tide level. We will continue to monitor the tidal forecast and update the situation as required.

items.description: South Cornwall Coast from Lands End to Lizard Point
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Saturday morning 07 January. High water at Newlyn is at 04.52am, times of high water will vary along the coast.
Strong force 8 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of between 4 and 5m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations in Mounts Bay.  Expect tides to be around 530mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Newlyn is 2.71 mAOD, this is 0.53 metres above astronomical tide level.

River levels are forecast to rise as a result of heavy rainfall overnight tonight, Friday (06/01/23), and into tomorrow, Saturday (07/01/23). Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible between 11:00 and 19:00 tomorrow (07/01/23). Areas most at risk are Skipton Washlands, Snaygill Ings and Cononley Washlands. We expect river levels to remain high until 02:00 on 08/01/23. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 20:00 PM on 06/01/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Cae Howel river gauge.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Further rainfall is expected early Saturday morning 07/01/23, this may cause river levels to rise again. We are closely monitoring the situation.
  
This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely this evening, Friday 6th January, into the early hours of tomorrow morning.  High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed.  We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas.  We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Saturday 7th January.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Barle, River Exe, River Lyn, River Mole, River Bray

items.message:
Flooding is possible from the early hours of Saturday 7th January. Heavy rain is expected from 1am in the morning and will cause river levels to rise.
We expect flooding to affect to low lying land and roads. Flood Warnings may be required.
Please take care near the areas of concern. Do not walk or drive through flood water. Avoid low lying roads and footpaths, which may be flooded.
Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation.
This message will be updated Saturday afternoon, or if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Strat, River Neet, River Ottery, River Kensey

items.message:
Flooding is possible Saturday 7th January from around 05:00am, continuing into the afternoon and evening.  

Heavy rain is forecast overnight tonight and into Saturday morning, especially over high ground where large totals are possible. The persistent rain is forecast to clear during Saturday morning, followed by heavy showers throughout the rest of Saturday and into Sunday. 

This may result in flooding to low lying land and roads close to the rivers from early morning on Saturday 7th January, persisting into the evening. We expect river levels to remain high throughout this period, though no flooding to properties is currently expected.  

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for, and clearing, blockages. This message will be updated if the situation changes.

Only 2mm of rain was recorded on the Western Rother on Thursday night. Between Liss and Midhurst, river levels are already near normal. At Fittleworth, the Western Rother is high, but slowly falling. Friday is forecast to remain mostly dry. River levels will continue to slowly fall. 10-20mm of rain is predicted on Saturday, with heavy showers Sunday and further periods of rain Tuesday and Wednesday (11/01/2023). Water could remain in fields for much of the week ahead. We will likely re-issue this message Saturday. There could be a chance of property flooding, if as much rain falls as forecast. Currently we think the greatest risk of flooding will affect the area between Lodsbridge and Fittleworth.

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Exmouth is 2.31mAOD, this is 0.53 metres above the astronomical tide level. We will continue to monitor the tidal forecast and update the situation as required.

A Flood Warning has been issued for West Bay Harbour for tomorrow mornings high tide,  Saturday 7th January 2023. The forecast is for strong winds, large waves and spray overtopping on the coast. We are expecting total water levels to be high for the high tide in the morning at 06:32am, with force 8 southerly winds. Conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk include the inner harbour, East Beach and the esplanade on East Beach. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. We will update this message by 12:00 PM on 07/01/2023 or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Beggearn Huish river gauge as a result of the ground being saturated and reacting to further rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible between 12 noon today  and 12 noon tomorrow, 07/01/23.  We expect flooding to affect the Horner Water, Rivers Aller and Washford, and the Hawkcombe, Monksilver and Doniford Streams and tributaries.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
  
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
  
This message will be updated on Saturday 07/01/23

A Flood Warning has been issued for tomorrow mornings high tide Saturday 7th January 2023. Water levels will be higher than normal due to a spring tide, a tidal surge, strong winds and large waves. The morning high tide at Preston Beach will be at 06:51 am with force 8 southerly winds. Flooding is possible at the Sea Life Centre and the Preston Beach Road area of Lodmoor. Conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. We continue to monitor the forecast and will re-issue this warning if necessary. This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 07/01/2023, or as the situation changes

River levels are high but steady at the Lugwardine river gauge.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further heavy and at times persistent rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are clearing debris from weed screens.  
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Plym, Tory Brook, Long Brook

items.message:
Flooding is possible tomorrow morning Saturday 7th January from around 05:00am, continuing into the afternoon and evening.    
  
Heavy rain is forecast overnight tonight and into Saturday morning, especially over high ground where large totals are possible. Catchments are very wet and river levels are likely to rise quickly in response to further rainfall.    
  
This may result in flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river from early morning on Saturday 7 January, lasting into the evening. The persistent rain is forecast to clear during Saturday morning, to be followed by heavy showers throughout the rest of Saturday and into Sunday.  We expect river levels to remain high throughout this period, though no flooding to properties is currently expected.    
   
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated by 5pm on Saturday 7th January, or earlier if the situation changes.

The Upper Bristol Avon flood alert is active and is expected to remain in force until Tuesday the 10 January 2023.
River levels remain high on the River Avon through Great Somerford, Sherston Avon and Tetbury Avon and above the Flood Alert criteria. Further rain is forecast tomorrow Saturday the 07 January 2023  with a further 3 to 15mm possible, which may result in flood warnings. We are monitoring this development and will provide an update tomorrow, or as the situation changes.
High river levels and bankfull conditions are expected throughout the catchment. Flooding is expected to affect the road at Reybridge. 

Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers and do not drive through flood water. We are monitoring the situation and checking for blockages in rivers.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.728 m and is falling by approximately 3 mm per hour. 
The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.656 m and is falling by approximately 3 mm per hour. 
Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long load if this level exceeds 7.86 and the road from Muchelney to Thorney if this level exceeds 7.93 m. Property flooding is possible if this level exceeds 8.35 m.
Pumping is taking place at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station.
Unsettled weather is forecast for Saturday evening.
The River Yeo at Muchelney is forecast to rise as a result.   
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
This message will be updated on Saturday 07/01/2023

Flooding is possible in this area. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. The Environment Agency Flood Warning System has issued this message based on rising river or tidal levels. We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are forecast to rise on the River Loddon as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, the risk of flooding remains, especially in the Winnersh and Sindlesham areas. Levels have fallen over the last few days after a mostly dry period but are likely to respond to the showers expected over the weekend. 

Further heavy rainfall is forecast over this evening and throughout the weekend. We expect river levels to begin rising on 07/01/23. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are in the area clearing weed and trash screens. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow afternoon, 07/01/23, or as the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.391 m and is falling by approximately 3 mm per hour.
Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45 m.
The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 6.435 and is falling by approximately 4 mm per hour.
There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if this level reaches 8.30 m.
Pumping is taking place at Currymoor pumping station.
Unsettled weather is forecast for Saturday evening into Sunday Morning.
The River Tone at Currymoor is forecast to  rise  as a result.   
We are closely monitoring the situation.     
This message will be updated on Saturday 07/01/23.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message:
The flood alert for the Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby remains in force as river levels remain high due to recent rainfall. The current river level at Naburn is 2.56m. The current river level in York is 2.86m. Levels will remain around this level throughout today, Friday 6th January 2023. Further rainfall is forecast for the weekend which will keep levels high but are not expected to rise significantly.

Low lying land around the River Ouse is at risk of flooding. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Visit the GOV.UK website for a 5-day flood forecast.  This message will be updated at approximately 9pm the evening 06/01/2023.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message:
The flood alert for the upper Ouse remains in force as river levels remain high due to recent rainfall. The current river level in York is 2.86m. Flooding is expected to affect locations near the River Ouse, with low lying land most affected, particularly around Riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith, and South Esplanade. Levels are expected to remain around this level throughout today, Friday 6th January 2023. Further rainfall is forecast for the weekend which will keep levels high but are not expected to rise significantly.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Visit the GOV.UK website for a 5-day flood forecast. This message will be updated at approximately 9pm the evening of 06/01/2023.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, York

items.message:
The flood alert for the Lower Derwent remains in force following recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads, particularly around Buttercrambe, Stamford Bridge, Elvington and Bubwith. Further rainfall is forecast for the weekend which will keep levels high, but are not expected to rise significantly.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Visit the GOV.UK website for a 5-day flood forecast. This message will be updated at approximately 9pm, the evening 06/01/2023.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high and stable on parts of the River Thame following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying paths, roads and land is expected to continue, especially in the Thame area and between Thame and the confluence with the River Thames. River levels on the Chalgrove Brook have dropped and flood risk here has reduced.
The forecast is for showers this afternoon (06/01/23) developing into a band of rain that may bring locally heavy rain overnight into tomorrow morning. We expect river levels to remain high over the coming days, and may rise upstream of Thame and in the Chalgrove Brook in response to the weekend's rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, be aware of flood water and avoid using low lying footpaths near watercourses. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 07/01/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames for the Abingdon area
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high but steady on the River Thames following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying paths, roads and land is expected to continue, especially close to the river in the Culham, Long Wittenham and Clifton Hampden areas. 
The forecast is for showers this afternoon (06/01/23) developing into a band of rain that may bring locally heavy rain overnight into tomorrow morning. We expect river levels to remain high over the coming days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are operating weirs to reduce flood risk. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, be aware of flood water and avoid using low lying footpaths near watercourses. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 07/01/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high and stable on parts of the River Cherwell following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying paths, roads and land is expected to continue, especially in areas close to the river in the Kidlington area. 
The forecast is for showers this afternoon (06/01/23) developing into a band of rain that may bring locally heavy rain overnight into tomorrow morning. We expect river levels to remain high over the coming days, and may rise in response to the weekend's rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, be aware of flood water and avoid using low lying footpaths near watercourses. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 07/01/23, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Tern - Walcot river gauge.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  This message will be updated as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message: Flooding is possible in this area. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. The Environment Agency Flood Warning System has issued this message based on rising river or tidal levels. We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible from the early hours of Saturday 7th January. Heavy rain is expected from 1am in the morning and will cause river levels to rise.
We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads. Flood Warnings may be required.
Please take care near the areas of concern. Do not walk or drive through flood water. Avoid low lying roads and footpaths, which may be flooded.
Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation.
This message will be updated Saturday afternoon, or if the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Mythe Bridge and Haw Bridge river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. Predicted peaks:- Mythe 3.4m to 3.8m Sunday evening, 08/01/2023, Haw Bridge 4.3m to 4.7m Sunday evening, 08/01/2023.  
We expect river levels to rise until Sunday evening, 08/01/2023. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Worcester (Barbourne) river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding of roads and farmland is possible overnight Friday, 06/01/2023. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Highley to Tewkesbury. Locations that may be affected are Stourport, Holt Fleet, Worcester, Kempsey, Severn Stoke, Upton upon Severn, South Quay, Diglis Parade and Hylton Road towpath. Flooded drains may affect the racecourse and Worcester County cricket ground. Predicted peaks:- Bewdley 3.3m to 3.8m on 07/01, Worcester 4.2m to 4.7m on 07/01, Kempsey Yacht Club 5.3m to 5.8m on 08/01, Saxons Lode 3.9m to 4.4m on 08/01.   

We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated if the situation changes.

This Flood Warning has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences and liaising with emergency services.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high and stable on parts of the River Glyme following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying paths, roads and land is expected to continue, especially in the Woodstock area. River levels on the River Evenlode have dropped and the flood risk has reduced.
The forecast is for showers this afternoon (06/01/23) developing into a band of rain that may bring locally heavy rain overnight into tomorrow morning. We expect river levels to remain high over the coming days, and may rise in response to the weekend's rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, be aware of flood water and avoid using low lying footpaths near watercourses. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 07/01/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Buildwas river gauge.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge and Bridgnorth. Floodplain at Leighton starts to fill. River Levels peaked at Welshbridge at 3.3m this morning, 06/01/23. Predicted Peaks:- Buildwas 4.1m to 4.5m Saturday morning 07/01/23, Bridgnorth 3.2m to 3.7m Saturday afternoon 07/01/23. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
  
This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high and stable on parts of the River Ray following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying paths, roads and land is expected to continue, especially in areas between Upper Arncott and Islip. 
The forecast is for showers this afternoon (06/01/23) developing into a band of rain that may bring locally heavy rain overnight into tomorrow morning. We expect river levels to remain high over the coming days. Upstream of Upper Arncott, river levels may rise in response to the weekend's rainfall. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, be aware of flood water and avoid using low lying footpaths near watercourses. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 07/01/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels are remaining high on the River Dee.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Dee.
Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington.
No property flooding is expected.
Further rainfall is forecast overnight.
River levels are expected to remain high over the weekend.
We will continue to work with emergency services and local authorities and to keep closely monitoring the situation.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 07/01/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Brimscombe river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Elmore to Sharpness. Other locations that may be affected include Chalford, Leonard Stanley and Cambridge.  
Predicted peaks:- Brimscombe 0.9m to 1.05m Sunday morning, 08/01/2023.  
We expect river levels to rise until Sunday morning.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Please avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible Saturday 7th January from around 04:15am, continuing into the afternoon and evening.  

Heavy rain is forecast overnight tonight and into Saturday morning, especially over high ground where large totals are possible. The persistent rain is forecast to clear during Saturday morning, followed by heavy showers throughout the rest of Saturday and into Sunday. 
 
This may result in flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river from early morning on Saturday 7th January, persisting into the early evening. We expect river levels to remain high throughout this period, though no flooding to properties is currently expected. 

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for, and clearing, blockages. This message will be updated if the situation changes.

Flooding is possible in this area. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. The Environment Agency Flood Warning System has issued this message based on rising river or tidal levels. We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
River levels have risen on the Hundred Foot Washes as a result of flood water moving down the River Great Ouse and into the Hundred Foot Washes.  Flooding is affecting Hundred Foot Washes, also known as the Ouse Washes, including the causeways at Sutton Gault and Welney.  We expect river levels to remain high on the Hundred Foot Washes for at least today. 

The gauge at Sutton Gault has a fault.  This information is correct as of 6am on 05/01/23, the causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 17 centimetres of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 15 centimetres of water on the road, this information is correct as of 3pm on 06/01/23.  Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. There are currently no issues on the Earith causeway.  The Environment Agency are liaising with Norfolk Highways, who will decide when to open Welney Causeway.

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 07/01/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Yeo and Parrett, downstream of Yeovil to Steart

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Parrett, River Yeo, Cary, Sowy, Kings Sedgemoor Drain

items.message:
River levels remain stable and are forecast to rise at the Ilchester river gauge as a result of the ground being saturated and reacting to further rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect the Ilchester to Yeovilton road at the end of the runway, the Mudford to Limington road and the road at the south end of Westover Trading Estate. Properties at Westover Trading Estate at Langport are at risk. Bankfull conditions are forecast at Ilchester and water will reach the bottom of the ringbanks at Ilchester Meads and Ilchester.   
Further heavy and at times persistent rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to begin rising overnight on 07/01/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and deploying pumps as required. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated Saturday 07/01/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Great Ouse in Cambridgeshire from Brampton to Earith
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels are falling. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Some rainfall is forecast on Saturday which may cause river levels to rise again.

items.description: Lower River Loddon at the River Thames confluence at Twyford
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are forecast to rise on the River Loddon as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, the risk of flooding remains, especially in the Twyford area. Levels have fallen over the last few days after a mostly dry period but are likely to respond to the showers expected over the weekend.

Further heavy rainfall is forecast over this evening and throughout the weekend. We expect river levels to begin rising on 07/01/23. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are in the area clearing weed and trash screens. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow afternoon, 07/01/23, or as the situation changes.

There is no longer a threat of flooding but standing water and debris may still remain. Although further rain is forecast over tonight, Friday the 6th of January, we are not expecting any further flooding. 
We will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue this alert if required. 
Stay away from floodwater - it can contain hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent, prolonged rainfall. Levels will continue to rise over the next few days and flooding of fields and some minor roads is expected.  Further rainfall is expected over the coming weekend. Due to a BT fault data from the Woodyates borehole is currently unavailable online, however today's reading is 93.95 metres above sea level.
Looking further ahead next week will be relatively dry, but with the possibility of stormy conditions appearing at the end of the week.

items.description: River Thames and its small tributaries from Calcutt to Lechlade

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Blunsdon Brook, Water Eaton Brook, Marston Meysey Brook, Share Ditch, Bydemill Brook, Westrop Brook, Downington Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high but steady on the River Thames following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying paths, roads and land is expected to continue, especially in areas closest to the river between Castle Eaton and Lechlade. 
The forecast is for showers this afternoon (06/01/23) developing into a band of rain that may bring locally heavy rain overnight into tomorrow morning. We expect river levels to remain high over the coming days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are operating weirs to reduce flood risk. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, be aware of flood water and avoid using low lying footpaths near watercourses. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 07/01/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high and forecast to rise further on the Rivers Lowther and Eamont due to rainfall on the evening of Friday the 6th into Saturday the 7th of January.
Further rainfall is forecast over the weekend which will cause the rivers to remain high.
Areas most at risk include Rivers Eamont and Lowther to their confluence with the River Eden at Langwathby.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated on Saturday the 7th of January or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Pang from East Ilsley to Pangbourne and Sulham Brook
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have fallen below the flood risk threshold. Showers will develop this afternoon (06/01/23) with a band of rain moving through early tomorrow morning (07/01/23). Showers, heavy at times, will continue through to Sunday (08/01/23)
We will continue to monitor the forecast and any river response and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and be aware of flood water remaining on the floodplain.

items.description: Clanfield Brook for Clanfield Village and the Shill Brook for Bampton
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have fallen below the flood risk threshold. Showers will develop this afternoon (06/01/23) with a band of rain moving through early tomorrow morning (07/01/23). Showers, heavy at times, will continue through to Sunday (08/01/23)
We will continue to monitor the forecast and any river response and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and be aware of flood water remaining on the floodplain.

items.description: Low lying roads between Harrold and Oakley in Bedfordshire
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall following the rainfall on New Year's Day.  Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing.  We believe there is still a possibility of flooding for roads close to the bridges at Harrold, Oakley, Felmersham and Radwell.   
Some rainfall is forecast on Saturday which could cause river levels to rise again. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 07/01/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message: We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.391 m and falling by approximately 3 mm per hour.
Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45 m.
The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 6.435 and is falling by approximately 3 mm per hour.
There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if this level reaches 8.30 m.
Pumping is taking place at Currymoor pumping station.
Unsettled weather is forecast for Saturday night into early Sunday morning on 07/01/2023.
The River Tone at Currymoor is forecast to rise.         
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
This message will be updated Saturday 07/01/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to recent rainfall and have risen at our observation borehole in Draycot Foliat in the Og Valley area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater over the coming days.

Groundwater levels in the area are slowly rising and responsive to rainfall. The forecast is for showers this afternoon (06/01/23) developing into a band of rain that may bring locally heavy rain overnight into tomorrow morning. We expect groundwater levels to rise slowly over the next few days in response to this rainfall. Low-lying land and roads will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message tomorrow (07/01/2023), or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Piddle Valley
items.message:
Following three months of above average rainfall, groundwater levels in the area have risen considerably, and with further rainfall forecast over the next ten days are set to rise yet further. Up to date groundwater levels for the area can be seen at Doles Ash groundwater monitoring site which can be accessed at check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk

Environment agency staff will continue to monitor the situation. Contact the local authority to report issues and for assistance or your flood warden for more local advice. 

Flooding of roads and some vulnerable properties is possible.

Residents may experience inundation of basements, septic tanks and sewer systems.

If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts.

Road surfaces may become damaged.

Please do not drive through floodwater as bow waves may affect adjacent properties.

Following three months of above average rainfall, groundwater levels in the area have risen considerably, and with further rainfall forecast over the next ten days are set to rise yet further. Up to date groundwater levels for the area can be seen at Dickley Down groundwater monitoring site which can be accessed at check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk

Environment agency staff will continue to monitor the situation. Contact the local authority to report issues and for assistance or your flood warden for more local advice. 

Flooding of roads and some vulnerable properties is possible.

Residents may experience inundation of basements, septic tanks and sewer systems.

If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts.

Road surfaces may become damaged.

Please do not drive through floodwater as bow waves may affect adjacent properties.

Environment agency staff will continue to monitor the situation. Contact the local authority to report issues and for assistance or your flood warden for more local advice.

If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts.

Road surfaces may become damaged.

Please do not drive through floodwater as bow waves may affect adjacent properties.

Flooding of roads and some vulnerable properties is possible.

Residents may experience inundation of basements, septic tanks and sewer systems.

If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts.

Road surfaces may become damaged.

Please do not drive through floodwater as bow waves may affect adjacent properties.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on parts of the River Windrush following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying paths, roads and land is expected to continue, especially in areas between Witney and the River Thames. 
The forecast is for showers this afternoon (06/01/23) developing into a band of rain that may bring locally heavy rain overnight into tomorrow morning. We expect river levels to remain high over the coming days. Upstream of Witney, river levels may rise in response to the weekend's rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, be aware of flood water and avoid using low lying footpaths near watercourses. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 07/01/23, or as the situation changes.

Flooding is possible in this area. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. The Environment Agency Flood Warning System has issued this message based on rising river or tidal levels. We are temporarily automating our messages due to industrial action.

This Flood Warning has been removed.  
River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.  The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences and liaising with emergency services.

items.description: River Severn at the Showground and The Quarry, Shrewsbury
items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Welshbridge river gauge. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect offices at the showground and Gravel Hill Lane. River Levels peaked at Welshbridge at 3.3m this morning, 06/01/23 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
  
This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Rame Head to Plymouth including tidal estuaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Saturday morning 07 January. High water at Plymouth is at 05.51am, times of high water will vary along the coast.
Strong force 8 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of between 4 and 5m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations.  Expect tides to be around 530mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Plymouth is 2.61 mAOD, this is 0.53 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle
items.message: In Finchdean and Rowlands Castle, groundwater levels are high and rising. Since 27th December 2022, almost a month’s rain (70mm) has been recorded at Worlds End. This is in addition to an extremely wet November 2022. In the last 24 hours, the groundwater level in Finchdean has increased by 0.69m. The Idsworth Lavant is expected to begin flowing on Sunday (08/01/2023). From Monday (09/01/2023), the level may become high enough where a small number of pumps may have to operate to prevent water from affecting property. Further rain (20 to 35mm) is forecast across Saturday and Sunday 08/01/2023. Groundwater levels in the valley are expected to rise until at least mid-January. With unsettled weather forecast for the rest of January, groundwater levels in the valley are likely to remain high or could rise even further in the coming weeks. Surface water may begin to flood property during heavier rain events. We are liaising with the Flood Action Group. Please ensure any pumps you use to help reduce water levels are able to operate. This message will be updated by 17:00 on Monday 09/01/2023.

items.description: River Piddle from Alton Pancras to Wareham
items.message: River levels have risen at the Little Puddle and Briantspuddle river gauges as a result of the ground being saturated and reacting to recent rainfall. Consequently there is a possibility of flooding for Alton Pancras, Piddletrenthide, Piddlehinton, Druce, Puddletown, Athelhampton, Affpuddle, Briantspuddle, Throop and Wareham including Purbeck View Park. Further rainfall is forecast over the weekend. Groundwater levels have risen in the last two weeks and so we expect river levels to remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are in contact with community flood wardens and volunteers. Please avoid using bridges over local watercourses and can owners with property flood resilience equipment install it now. This message will be updated Saturday 07/01/23, or as the situation changes.
